summary: gene-wide association analyses were performed using gene expression microarray values measured on a log2 scale. an LRS score >17 was significant and an LRS score >10 was suggestive at a genome-wide P value of 0.05. using the WEB-based GEne SeT AnaLysis Toolkit (WebGestalt) we also used the oPOSSUM-3 Web-based tool (Kwon et al. 2012) to identify overrepresentation of transcription factor binding sites. we also integrated ChIP-seq data from two previously published data sets. sections were washed in TBS (pH 7.4) and incubated in anti-TNNI3 primary antibody. sections were then washed in TBS for 1 hr before incubating in mouse on mouse polymer (Abcam) for 30 min, washed in TBS, and incubated with diaminobenzidine (0.4 mg/ml, 3 min) gene-wide association analyses were performed using gene expression microarray values measured on a log2 scale. an LRS score >17 was significant and an LRS score >10 was suggestive at a genome-wide P value of 0.05 using 5000 permutations. gene ontology (GO) using the WEB-based GEne SeT AnaLysis Toolkit (WebGestalt) we also used the oPOSSUM-3 Web-based tool (Kwon et al. 2012) to identify overrepresentation of transcription factor binding sites. sections were washed in TBS (pH 7.4) and incubated in anti-TNNI3 primary antibody. sections were counterstained with mayers hematoxylin, blued with Scotts Tap Water Substitute, washed and dehydrated through graded alcohols to xylene. the expression of TNNI3 has previously been used as a marker for pulmonary myocardium. the expression of TNNI3 in whole-lung data sets would also be expressed in the pulmonary myocardium. we found 24 transcripts that were significantly associated at a Pearson correlation >0.8. the top 100 transcripts that correlated with Tnni3 in the BXD whole-lung transcriptome data set were used to generate a network graph. this resulted in a network of 24 transcripts with a Pearson correlation >0.8. all proteins except DOC2G and MYBPHL had known roles in cardiac function. two myosin heavy chains, two essential myosin light chains and two regulatory myosin light chains interact to form the thick filament of the sarcomere. mylk3 Myosin light chain kinase 3 Phosphorylates MYLC2a to facilitate actin–myosin interaction and muscle contraction. ln Sarcolipin Trdn Triadin Forms a complex with Ryr2 to coordinate release of calcium from the SR. the top 100 transcripts correlated with Acta2 were enriched for smooth muscle-associated genes including gamma-actin 2 (Actg2), leiomodin (Lmod2), transgelin (Tagln), and calponin 1 (Cnn1). the pulmonary myocardium gene network is coregulated from loci on Chr1 and Chr2. all probe pairs within this set of 24 transcripts were positively correlated. heat-map analysis of eQTL for all 24 transcripts highlighted prominent regions of shared covariance on Chr1 and 2 with possible minor regions on Chr3, Chr4, Chr13, and Chr17. expression levels of multiple transcripts in this gene network were coordinatedly regulated by a shared set of cis and trans eQTL expression level of all transcripts varied by greater than twofold between BXD strains. expression level of all transcripts varied by greater than twofold between the highest and lowest expressing BXD strains. 12 of the remaining transcripts had a suggestive eQTL overlapping the Chr2: 68.8 0.4 Mb region (Figure 2E) all transcripts interval contained nine genes, three of which were expressed at appreciable levels in adult lung (Lass6, Nostrin, and Lrp2) but only two had known roles in gene regulation (Nostrin) or cell signaling (Lrp2). the transcription factors NKX2-5, SRF, MEF2A, TEAD1 and NR2F1 potentially cooperate to specify and/or maintain pulmonary myocardium identity. we interrogated previously published NKX2-5 ChIP-seq data derived from two sources. we also examined NKX2-5 enrichment at our candidate pulmonary myocardium control loci on Chr1 and Chr2. we also found NKX2-5 enrichment at Rab23, Zfp451 and Nostrin in the He et al. data set. NKX2-5 could directly regulate expression of the pulmonary myocardium gene network. the pulmonary myocardium gene network was enriched in binding site sequences for SRF (serum response factor; 10 genes), TEAD1 (TEA Domain Family Member 1; 14 genes), NR2F1 (Nuclear Receptor Subfamily 2, Group F, Member 1; 12 genes), and MEF2A (Myocyte Enhancer Factor 2A; 18 genes). the absence of Nkx2-5 expression in adult lung is an apparent paradox. however, whether the lung sections sampled in the Fantom5 project actually contain pulmonary myocardium cannot be determined. pulmonary myocardium gene network and coexpressed genes are associated with cardiac phenotypes overlapping those of the stressed heart. the pulmonary myocardium gene coexpression network was significantly enriched with GO terms involving biological processes related to both striated and cardiac muscle function and development. enriched cellular components included contractile fiber and sarcomeric genes. 12 3.35e14 SR Trdn Triadin Forms a complex with Ryr2 to coordinate release of calcium from the SR Ventricular tachycardia, long QT syndrome (Roux-buisson et al. 2012; Altman et al. 2015) no change Myoz2 Myozenin 2 The protein encoded by this gene binds to calcineurin, a phosphatase involved in calcium-dependent signal transduction in diverse cell types. no change Gja3 Gap junction protein, -3, 46 kDa (Connexin 46) the protein encoded by this gene is a connexin. the protein is a component of lens fiber gap junctions. ACTC1 was selected as its transcript was highly expressed in the lung data set (12.422 units) and was part of our pulmonary myocardium gene coexpression network. further, Actc1 has previously been shown to be a direct target of NKX2-5 (Chen et al. 1996). a thin muscle coat positively staining for ACTA2 was situated beneath the columnar epithelium. staining of ACTC1 but not TNNI3 was detected in bronchial smooth muscle cells. no positive staining was detected with an isotype control antibody. serial sections of lung tissue were immunostained for (A) ACTA2, (B) TNNI3, (C) ACTC1 and (D) IgG isotype control (Isotype) we have used a systems-genetics approach to examine a large network of coexpressed genes simultaneously without prior knowledge of their identity. by correlating variation in gene expression and known BXD genotypes in a genome-wide eQTL analysis we identified three regulatory loci associated with the expression of a cardiac gene network in the pulmonary myocardium. the eQTL interval located at Chr1: 33 1 Mb contained two possible candidates for regulating expression of the pulmonary myocardium gene network. the eQTL interval located at Chr1: 33 1 Mb contained two possible candidates for regulating expression of the pulmonary myocardium gene network. TTN regulates the passive stretch of cardiomyocytes via the I-band region of the protein which is comprised of sequential Ig, PEVK, and N2B domains. alternative splicing of Ttn results in a shorter ventricular isoform (N2B) and a longer atrial isoform (N2BA) both FHL2 and CARP have been shown to act as transcription factors in response to specific stimuli. CARP is upregulated at the myofibril and in the nucleus in response to stretch. CARP overexpression in murine neonatal cardiomyocytes represses expression of Anf, Actc1, Acta1, MHC, ventricular myosin light chain 2 (Myl2) and cardiac troponin C (Tnnc) hemodynamic changes trigger mechanosensory (stretch-stress) signaling from the sarcomere via TTN and initiate NO signaling cascades which are transmitted to the myocyte nucleus via NOSTRIN. these signals initiate dynamic regulation of gene expression to enable fine-tuning of the contractile properties of the pulmonary myocardium. BM20 is associated with altered splicing and expression levels of >200 genes. it is also likely to be an important regulator of the pulmonary myocardium molecular phenotype. the authors conclude that RBM20 underpins structural and functional development of cardiomyocytes. this gene is expressed at low levels in our gene network but is regulated from a suggestive eQTL on Chr1: 33. upregulation of Cacna2d2 subsequent to dysregulation of our gene network could predispose to gain of pacemaker activity. TBX5 is an essential factor for development of the cardiac conduction system. genes/loci identified in this study could be linked to atrial fibrillation in humans triggered by pulmonary events. this leads to dynamic regulation of gene expression, enabling fine-tuning of the contractile properties of the pulmonary myocardium. these loci regulate genes that in humans are known to be associated with various heart diseases.
